Description: An introduction to the French language in the context of Francophone cultures.
A continuation of the introduction to the French language in the context of Francophone cultures.
Continued development of speaking, listening, reading and writing skills using a variety of cultural materials.
Continuation of FR 23201.
(Repeatable for a maximum of 9 credit hours)Topic to be announced in the schedule of classes.

A course designed to enhance students' oral proficiency through instruction in facilitating conversation and the
discussion of culture-based texts.

A course designed to develop writing and reading skills, and in particular to prepare students to read and write
about French literature.

Designed to develop writing and reading skills, and in particular to prepare students to read and write about
French literature.

Study of sounds of French language and their relation to spelling; application of international phonetic alphabet
to French. Study augmented by recordings.

Translation practice with French texts using principles and techniques learned in the lecture class. To be taken
concurrently with TRST 30230.

Course Name: CONVERSATION FOR BUSINESS AND SPECIAL PURPOSES:FRENCH
Description:
Introduction to the special vocabulary of business and other special subject areas;introduces the concept of
language for special purposes and emphasizes the use of special vocabulary in conversations in business and
other settings.

Evolution of French dramatic literature from the middle ages to the present. Readings of representative works
with lectures analyses. In French.

Evolution of French poetry from the middle ages to the present. Readings of representative works with lectures
analyses. In French.

Evolution of French novel from 17th century to present. Readings of representative major works lectures
analyses. In French.
A survey of French history and culture from its beginnings to World War II. Taught in French.

Prerequisites: One course from FR33335 or FR 33336 or FR 33337.
Description: (Repeatable for credit) (Cross-listed with FR 53091) Topic to be announced.

(Repeatable for credit) Workshops individually designed to provide instruction and training in specific areas of
French studies.

(Repeatable for a maximum of 6 credit hours)Allows the advanced, serious student to carry out research study
project on French literature, language or culture. Prior approval of supervising faculty members department
required.

Prerequisites: FR 33335 or FR 33336 or FR 33337 or FR 33421.
Description:
(Cross-listed with FR 53213) French stylistics developed by analyses of literary extracts and practice in written
expression.

(Cross-listed with FR 53216) A study of selected sociological, political, cultural or economic issues in the
contemporary Francophone world.

Theory and practice course that discusses translation theory and emphasizes French-to-English translation of
selected texts in business, technology, medicine and law.

Survey of the typical text types of business in the French culture and language. Practice sessions focus on
reading and understanding specialized texts and on the translation and composition of selected special texts in
French.

Studies of selected 20th century French novels, with detailed study of the novel of one or several major writers
or movements.

(Cross-listed with FR 53369) A study of selected poetry of Apollinaire, Breton, Mansour, Eluard, Michaux, Char,
Reverdy, Ponge, Guillevic, Jabes, Bonnefoy, Dupin, Albiach and others. Emphasis is placed on the relationship
between poetry and the visual arts in the 20th century.
(Cross-listed with FR 53370) Studies in French drama since 1900.
(Repeatable for credit) (Cross-listed with FR 43091) Topic to be announced.
French stylistics developed through analyses of literary extracts and practice in written expression.

(Cross-listed with FR 43216) A study of selected sociological, political, cultural or economic issues in the
contemporary Francophone world.
Study of selected 20th-century French novels, with emphasis on one or several major writers or movements.

(Cross-listed with FR 43369) A study of selected poetry of Apollinaire, Breton, Mansour, Eluard, Michaux, Char,
Reverdy, Ponge, Guillevic, Jabes, Bonnefoy, Dupin, Alpiach and others. Emphasis is placed on the relationship
between poetry and the visual arts in the 20th century.
(Cross-listed with FR 43370) Studies in French drama since 1900.
Students apply linguistic and communication science concepts to case studies of language mediation.

(Repeatable for credit) Workshops individually designed to provide instruction and training in specific areas of
French studies.

(Repeatable for credit)Research or individual investigation for master's level graduate students. Credits earned
applied toward degree requirements if department approves.

Thesis students must register for a total of 6 hours, 2 to 6 hours in a single semester distributed over several
semesters if desired.
Introduction to the fundamentals of French grammar for graduate students. Practice in reading and translation.

Translation of documents from a variety of literary and cultural sources, including literature, expository and
journalistic prose, scholarly treatises and essays. Translation into French will also be emphasized.

An introduction to methods and resources for the translation of commercial, economic, financial, legal,
diplomatic and governmental documents.

An introduction to methods and resources for the translation of scientific, technical, industrial and medical
documents.
Thesis students must continue registration each semester until all degree requirements are met.

Students will be responsible for a major translation and a terminology glossary as well as a critical analysis of
the source text, the problems encountered during the translation process and the strategies used to solve them.
